intro: Musa × paradisiaca var. rubra, commonly known as the red banana, is a cultivar of the banana plant characterized by its striking red or pink peel when unripe. This variety belongs to the Musaceae family and is native to Southeast Asia, where it is cultivated for both ornamental and culinary purposes. The plant produces large, elongated fruits that typically turn yellow when ripe, though the red coloration remains prominent even after ripening. It thrives in tropical climates with high humidity and well-drained soil, requiring consistent moisture and warm temperatures for optimal growth. The red banana is often used in decorative settings due to its vibrant appearance, but it is also edible and can be consumed when fully mature.
